DEMANDS STRICTER OBEDIENCE
Student Council Takes Steps to Insure
Enforcement of Freshman Regulations by Whole University Instead
of by Any One Class.

•

A pledge has been submitted to
the Student Council by the sophomores, binding the members of
that class not to participate in
any hazing disturbances during
the remainder of the university
year. Another pledge has been received from the Freshman Class,
pledging all its members to obey
the freshman regulations, in the
future, to the letter.
Following the reception of these
two communications, the Student
Council decided that the enforcement of the freshman regulations
was to be forever a matter for
the whole University, and that action taken by any one class, as a
class, would be met with the severest penalty. If any freshman
is found to have broken his pledge,
however, the matter is to be open
to any member of the University
who sees fit to take action.
In other words, any freshman
who leaves his skull cap at home,
or smokes in the Gilman Hall
basement, or does any other of
the things prohibited by the Student Council, may expect to meet
with summary punishment from
the nearest bystanders, instead of
punishment meted . out by the
sophomores as a class.
The pledges to abstain from all
class disorder apply to the banquets to be held in the spring, as
well as to hazing. Any freshman
or sophomore who attempts to
start anything of a pugnastic nature during this period will be acting in direct violation of these
pledges, and, in all probability,
will be summarily expelled.
The Council is equally determined to prevent the revival of
hazing at the University on account of any failure of freshmen
to obey reasonable rules, and consequently will see that the freshman regulations are strictly enforced. It believes that, when it
is clearly recognized that responsibility for the enforcement of
such rules is not in the hands of
the sophomores, but belongs to the
whole college, not only will class
disorders be eliminated, but the
regulations themselves will be
much more rigorously carried out.
Announcement has been made
by the Council that the remainder
of the freshman caps which were
ordered will arrive at the University this week. All freshmen who
are not supplied with these caps
are requested to hand in their
names, in order that there may be
no confusion in the distribution.

CLASS DEBATING TEAMS CHOSEN
Steinbach, Edgett and Oppenheimer to
Represent Seniors; Duncan, Rothschild
and Evans,Juniors—Hopkins' Subject Selected for the Triang'e.

At tryouts held last Wednesday
and Thursday, Alexander A. Steinbach, Eugene A. Edgett and Reuben Oppenheimer, with Lawrence
H. Baker as alternate, were chosen
as the members of the senior debating team; and Robert R. Duncan, Morton K. Rothschild and
Henry C. Evans, with Martin B.
Kohn as alternate, were selected
as the representatives of the
juniors.
The debate will be held on Saturday, March 3. The subject for
debate will be: "Resolved, That,
constitutionally waived, legislation providing for the compulsory
arbitration of labor disputes in
public utilities, and prohibiting
all strikes and lockouts in such
utilities, should be enacted."
This subject, submitted by the
Hopkins Debating Council for the
North Carolina-Virginia-Hopkins
-triangle, has just been selected
by the votes of the three universities as time question for that
contest. It received the second
votes of both the Virginia and
North Carolina Debating Councils, each university, of course,
voting for its own subject first.
It is possible, however, that the
term "public utilities" may be
changed to "interstate railroads,"
as it has been found that the latter phrase would probably make
the debate more concrete. This
suggestion was made by Virginia
in its last communication, and,
having been voted upon favorably
by the Hopkins council, is now before North Carolina for consideration.
The two class teams do not expect to do much work upon the
debate until after the examinations. The decision as to side will
be made by the toss of a coin,
sometime during the course of the
present week. Meanwhile, all that
the teams expect to do during the
remainder of the month is to acquaint themselves, in a general
way, with the import and the various phases of their subject.
If the change in the triangle
subject is approved by the North
Carolina council, the same change
will be made for the interclass
debate.
The tryouts for the Adams
Medal contest, for which only
sophomores are eligible, will be
held on Friday, January 26, at 1
P. M., in the assembly hall of the
Civil Engineering Building. • Dr.
John C. French will act as judge.

Practically all the arrangements for the field and track
meet between' the sophomore and
freshman classes, which takes
place on Saturday, January 27,
in the cage of the old gymnasium on Monument and Howard
streets, have been completed. The
officials have been chosen, the
invitations have been issued, and
all entries have been made.
Melamet and Weech are those
upon whom rest the hopes of the
sophs. Many will recall the superb showing Weech made last
year in the short dashes and the
broad jump. Though he has a
good opportunity to carry off the
laurels in the latter event, it is
uncertain, however, whether his
speed will surpass that of Beverly
Smith, the captain and crack
sprinter of the freshman team.
Melamet will enter almost every
event of the meet, and the sophs
are confident that he will carry
off a large number of first and second honors. Probably the closest
races will be those in which he
and Smith are entered.
Smith's ability as a sprinter
came to light in the meets of last
spring, when he won several first
places in the quarter and 220-yard
dash. These will be his big races
in the coming meet, and the freshies are sure that he will win the
meet for them. Among the numerous other candidates for the
first-year team are Bratt, a sprinter of no mean ability, and Bowen,
its best distance man.
As usual, there will be twelve
events, one of which is the seniorjunior relay race. The senior
four have run victoriously in three
previous meets, and hope to establish their record by carrying off
the honors in this one. Those on
the senior relay team are Straus
(captain), P. W. Sutton, E. G.
Hall and W. Weeks. The junior
team consists of R. N. Dempster
.(captain), F. Sutton, P. Wiggins,
0. P. Winslow and A. Golder.
G. H. Shawn is captain of the
sophomore team M. B. Carroll is
the manager.
The officers of the freshman
team are B Smith, captain, and
F. H. Townsend, manager.
Everyone is cordially invited to
attend the meet. Admission is
free.

Enforcing the Freshman Regulations.

The proclamation of the Student Council, printed elsewhere on
this page, crystallizes the theory
which has underlain the entire existence of the freshman regulations. The Council desires that
it be recognized, once and for all,
that the enforcement of these regulations lies, not with any one
class, but with the University as
a whole, and that it is the duty
of every member of the University
to take immediate action upon
any violation of those regulations
which he sees.
The pledge of strict conformity
to the rules which the freshmen
have given to the Council should
form the end of a period. Obedience to the regulations has heretofore been entirely too sporadic,
too dependent upon the personal
volition of the freshman concerned. Nor, in the great majority of cases, has the transgression
met with any penalty whatsoever.
" The regulations, if they are to
fulfil the purpose for which they
were created, must be obeyed universally, and to the letter. To
that end, the individual students
of the University should unite in
using the power which the Council has bestowed upon them. Any
freshman, who, in the future, is
found to be disobeying a single
one of the regulations—involving,
of course, the breaking of his
pledge—should meet with treatment as efficacious as it is summary.

A PROCLAMATION FROM THE STUDENT COUNCIL
After several conferences with the Faculty Committee on
Student Affairs, and many meetings in private, the Student
Council wishes to make the following proclamation to the student body:
"The action taken by the two lower classes during the past
week recognizes the fact that Freshman regulations at Hopkins
are not enforced by hazing. Both classes have agreed to this
principle. The Freshman class has voted to obey the Freshman regulations, and in the future to refrain from any hostile
act towards the Sophomores; and the Sophomores have agreed
not to take the college law into their own hands.
"If any Freshman so far forgets himself as to violate the
pledge which his class has taken, every undergraduate in the
University—Freshman,Sophomore,Junior,and Senior—is asked
to call his attention to the fact and to force him to adhere to
the regulations. Forcing the Freshman to do this, immediately after the offense has occurred, is not considered hazing.
The Freshmen themselves should co-operate and see that their
fellow-classmen obey the regulations. All kidnapping, putting
through stunts, night parties and the like are done away with.
"A class-rush between the Sophomores and Freshmen immediately following an athletic contest,on the scene of the contest, is not considered an infringement of the above rules.
"All Freshmen who have lost their caps should immediately
turn in their names to Mr. John Myers, at the postoffice, and
pay him 50 cents. He will then give a receipt for this amount
and later when the caps, which are now on their way, arrive,
each Freshman having a receipt will be given a cap. Freshmen holding receipts will be exempted from the rule of wearing their caps (until they arrive)."

Hopkins Engineering Society, Edward M. Stuart was elected president, following the resignation of

pressure of studies and work necessitated Baker's giving up the
position. Baker is now an officer
in the unit of Reserve Officers'
Corps at Johns Hopkins. He was
a member of the Black and Blue

greater conception of the theoretical study in the different courses.

the largest audiences that has attended a meeting this year, enjoyed a most interesting lecture

P. Telephone Company, on "The
Romance of the Telephone," in the
Mechanical and Electrical Building lecture hall. The lecture,
which was illustrated, followed
the great advance of the telephone
through its stages of advancement.
After the talk, lunch was served
in the basement of the building.

pair of balances in her left hand.

concluded, "when you look upon
man, think of God; when you look
the worm, think of the butterfly."

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—May I ask the privilege of
your columns to call to the attention of your readers the pending
formation by the American Ambulance Field Service in France
of several new sections, and the
opportunity which will be available during the next few months
for an additional number of volunteers who are interested in
France and who would like to be
of service there?
We have already more than two
hundred cars driven by American
volunteers, mostly university men,
grouped in sections which are attached to divisions of the French
army. These sections have served
at the front in Flanders, on the

Somme, on the Aisne, in Champagne, at Verdun (five sections,
including 120 cars, at the height
of the battle), in Lorraine and in
reconquered Alsace, and one of
our veteran sections has received
the signal tribute from the French
army staff of being attached to
the French army of the Orient in
the Balkans. We are now on the
point of greatly enlarging our
service for the last lap of the war,
and a considerable number of new
places are available.
Every American has reason to
be proud of the chapter which
these few hundred - American
youths have written into the history of this prodigious period.
Each of the several sections of the
American Ambulance Field Serv• ice, as a whole, and fifty-four of
their individual members have
been decorated by the French
army with the Croix de Guerre
or the Medaille Militaire for valor
in the performance of their work.
The nature of this work, and
the reason for these remarkable
tributes from the army of France,
is clearly presented in the official
report of the first year and a
half's Service, published by Houghton, Mifflin & Company, of Boston, under the title of "Friends
of France."
Information as to the requirements of and qualifications for the
service will be gladly sent by
Henry D. Sleeper from the Boston
headquarters of the Field Service,
at Lee Higginson & Company's,
40 State street, or may be obtained from William R. Hereford
at the New York headquarters, 14
Wall street.
The American Ambulance Field
Service has recently been described by a member of General
Joffre's staff as "the finest flower
of the magnificent wreath offered
by the Great America to her little
Latin sister."
There are surely many more of
the sterling youths of America
who would like to add their little
to that wreath.
A. PIATT ANDREW,
Inspector General, American
Ambulance Field Service.

TO HAVE TALKS ON VOCATIONS

STUART NOW HEADS ENGINEERS

Y. M. C. A. Plans Series of Addresses
Presenting Phases of Various Professions—First Talk Wednesday,
by Dr. Hugh Birckhead.

Is Elected President of Engineering
Society Upon Resignation of Henry
Baker—Mr. Martin Delivers
Interesting Address.

On Wednesday, January 24, at
1 P. M. there will be held in the
Donovan Room under the auspices
of the University Young Men's
Christian Association the first of
a series of "Life Work" talks. Dr.
Hugh Birckhead, of the Emmanuel P. E. Church,will speak on the
principles which should guide one
in choosing a profession.
It is planned in the near future
to have presented the opportunities in the field of medicine, law,
ministry, missions, insurance,
banking, real estate and the like.
These talks will be given by prominent men and will be of interest
to every student, since they present an all-important problem in
the life of the university man.
Wednesday has been chosen as
the day on which the students can
best spare a half-hour in the middle of the day, because of the
small number of men who have
laboratories on that afternoon,
and a large attendance is desired
and expected.
Chapel leader for the coming
week will be Dr. John C. French,
of the English department.

At a recent meeting of the Johns
Hopkins Engineering Society, Edward M. Stuart was elected president, following the resignation of
Henry S. Baker from that office.
Members of the Society expressed sincere regret that the
pressure of studies and work necessitated Baker's giving up the
position. Baker is now an officer
in the unit of Reserve Officers'
Corps at Johns Hopkins. He was
a member of the Black and Blue
lacrosse team last year, and
played a fine game at one of the
defense positions.
Edward Stuart, who was chosen
to fill Baker's position, was formerly chairman of the mechanical
engineering branch of the Society.
Following his resignation from
that position on being elected
president of the Society, William
D. Cecil was chosen by the members of the Society as chairman of
the mechanical branch.
The student heads of the various
departments are now, Stanley L.
Howard, of the civil engineering
branch; Louis McC. Young, of the
electrical engineering branch; and
W. D. Cecil, of the mechanical engineering branch. These men will
arrange meetings, which are to be
held every three weeks. Each
branch of the engineering department alternately has charge of the
meetings.
It is the idea of the Society to
have leading engineers in the various lines and of this vicinity to
talk to the Society on the practical problems that confront the
modern engineer. The students
will thus receive a practical
knowledge that will give them a
greater conception of the theoretical study in the different courses.
On Wednesday morning, at 11
o'clock, the Society, with one of
the largest audiences that has attended a meeting this year, enjoyed a most interesting lecture
by Mr. J. 0. Martin, of the C. &
P. Telephone Company, on "The
Romance of the Telephone," in the
Mechanical and Electrical Building lecture hall. The lecture,
which was illustrated, followed
the great advance of the telephone
through its stages of advancement.
After the talk, lunch was served
in the basement of the building.

MENORAH LECTURER COINS
NEW WORD—"EUCONOMICS"

The Johns Hopkins Menorah
Society had its most successful
meeting for the year when the
Rev. J. Leonard Levy delivered
an address before an audience of
over sixty students in the Donovan Room last Wednesday at 1
o'clock. The subject of his discussion was "The Butterfly, or a New
Name for an Old Theory of Better Social Order."
This theory, which the speaker
presented and advocated most eloquently and convincingly in the
course of his lecture, he named
by adding the Greek word "en
(good)" to "economics (the law
of the home)," thus making "euconomics (the good, or beautiful,
law of the home)." The purpose
of this theory may be best understood by quoting an excerpt from
Dr. Levy's lecture, which reads as
follows:
"Justice is generally represented as a woman, blindfolded, with
a sword in her right hand and a
pair of balances in her left hand.
The purpose and ideal of 'enconornics' is to put a living feeling heart into her cold and unsympathetic breast.
"Thus, gentlemen," the speaker
concluded, "when you look upon
man, think of God; when you look
the worm, think of the butterfly."
The officers of the Menorah Society wish, through THE NEWSLETTER, to thank the Christian
members of the student body who

took advantage of their invitation, and desire to again extend
a cordial invitation to them and
all other Hopkins men to be present at all future meetings. Dr.
Harry Edelson will address the
Society at the next regular meeting, which will be held on February 14, at 1 o'clock, in the Donovan Room.

Work of Ambulance Corps Described.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—May I ask the privilege of
your columns to call to the attention of your readers the pending
formation by the American Ambulance Field Service in France
of several new sections, and the
opportunity which will be available during the next few months
for an additional number of volunteers who are interested in
France and who would like to be
of service there?
We have already more than two
hundred cars driven by American
volunteers, mostly university men,
grouped in sections which are attached to divisions of the French
army. These sections have served
at the front in Flanders, on the

Somme, on the Aisne, in Champagne, at Verdun (five sections,
including 120 cars, at the height
of the battle), in Lorraine and in
reconquered Alsace, and one of
our veteran sections has received
the signal tribute from the French
army staff of being attached to
the French army of the Orient in
the Balkans. We are now on the
point of greatly enlarging our
service for the last lap of the war,
and a considerable number of new
places are available.
Every American has reason to
be proud of the chapter which
these few hundred - American
youths have written into the history of this prodigious period.
Each of the several sections of the
American Ambulance Field Serv• ice, as a whole, and fifty-four of
their individual members have
been decorated by the French
army with the Croix de Guerre
or the Medaille Militaire for valor
in the performance of their work.
The nature of this work, and
the reason for these remarkable
tributes from the army of France,
is clearly presented in the official
report of the first year and a
half's Service, published by Houghton, Mifflin & Company, of Boston, under the title of "Friends
of France."
Information as to the requirements of and qualifications for the
service will be gladly sent by
Henry D. Sleeper from the Boston
headquarters of the Field Service,
at Lee Higginson & Company's,
40 State street, or may be obtained from William R. Hereford
at the New York headquarters, 14
Wall street.
The American Ambulance Field
Service has recently been described by a member of General
Joffre's staff as "the finest flower
of the magnificent wreath offered
by the Great America to her little
Latin sister."
There are surely many more of
the sterling youths of America
who would like to add their little
to that wreath.
A. PIATT ANDREW,
Inspector General, American
Ambulance Field Service.
January 20, 1917.
